body:
@rabbah @csantanapr 
There are many test cases in system/basic related to the actions created by installCatalog. They will fail when openwhisk does not install the catalog. Since all the catalog is moved to openwhisk-catalog, the test cases deleted here in openwhisk, will be available in openwhisk-catalog. 

I will keep this PR alive, because openwhisk-catalog can refer to it for empty catalog. 
I can do the deletion of catalog incrementally.
We should not lose most of the tests you pointed out. They should rather be refactored to not rely on the catalog anymore (for the ones it makes sense obviously)

It looks like my comments in the commit all disappeared during the rebase.  The only change not related to the auth check is a change to the property command help text that I noticed was incorrect while using `wsk property` in testing wsk without any --auth setting.
@csantanapr @saschoff91 while at it, shall we add http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37887584/using-iconv-in-bluemixs-openwhisk
rebase and merged 00ec23d5133da26c66a3fd3946d528c1677489ba
PG please
PG please
PG please
There are no tests for the --lib flag.
There are no tests for any of these changes. These missing tests are documented here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/771.
If we lack test coverage here, we should add these tests before merging this.
@rabbah, IPG 215.
None of the switches have been flipped to test the Go CLI. There is an issue open for adding tests once the Go CLI is used for the automated tests.
It looks like it was a kafka problem and not docker, we will stick with 1.9.1 to have a good devops story, sicne 1.9.1 its what we use to deploy.
Generally we should deliver new features with their tests ;)
rebase and merged a0b4c1dc112ffcad8a9bb33601de7d19d164fcff
@dubeejw - Good point.  All 400+ tests for both python and Go CLI pass in my local env.
pg 217 queued
@dubeejw - Ready for review.  All tests for both python and Go passed locally.
I completely agree. Not sure why the tests weren't created when the features were added to the Python CLI.
I will add the tests when https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/809 is merged as that enables the action test suite to run against the Go CLI.
@rabbah sure and also update  watson-developer-cloud to latest I think @l2fprod wanted this.
Missing CLI tests: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/771.
@csantanapr, please merge.
give me a chance to review please.
How about pkgcloud too for all things openstack (mainly swift storage)?

@dubeejw - What exactly is the way to flip the test switch (Python -> Go CLI)?  I thought I changed it correctly, but now I'm suspicious.  Let's Hold off on merge until we have a chance to talk tomorrow.
rebase and merged c1f83681a3a48edef4c40fdfad8cdf4a3329469a

@mdeuser PG please.
@rabbah assigned to you when PG pass and you OK the review.
assigned when PG number is provided.
delegating to @rabbah to block because of tests, or merge without tests.
Hi @l2fprod this one? https://www.npmjs.com/package/pkgcloud
@csantanapr yes

Having tested locally, I can confirm this issue has been resolved.
Rebased and merged as f0a702ff44a4b5c5ae3fc13242318025b1c9bb26
IPG 219 green
`ConsulClient` LGTM
The changes look good to me. Are we waiting for one thumb up per assignee? Happy to squash and merge after that.
squashed.
@lfzCarlosC is this issue still valid?
@houshengbo this is still a valid issue?
The Go CLI is not tested currently, but I will run the tests anyway.
@mdeuser, please review.
Resolved by #738

> Note that this is a breaking API change as existing actions might stop working when run in nodejs 6.

This was implemented in such a way that existing "nodejs" actions are unaffected, and will continue to run on the Node 0.12 runtime.

I tested Kafka 0.10.0.0 (scala 2.11) and changing the server alone did not fix this.  However, using the 0.10.0.0 client libs appear to have fixed the problem.  I will be retesting this and hopefully then adding a new unit test with a name like (aaa.aaa....) so that it runs first as soon after deploy as possible.

@csantanapr - I will open a new issue to document that promises can now be used instead of async and done as Steve had suggested.  Where should we document this?  I see doc references for using async in references.md and actions.md.  Is this where the promises documentation should go?  Should we remove the references to async in the doc?
I am going to add a simple sample action showing how an action can return a promise and add a test that uses the sample.

Unfortunately retesting showed the problem is still present and now appears to be hitting the controller->invoker path instead.  This is slightly comforting because at least it's not specific to a path which makes no sense.  But back to the drawing board....

So it's not that the period of badness is 5 minutes.  Every single post is held back for about 5 minutes.  This was obscured (mitigated) by active ack timing out so that 30 seconds seem like the timing to look for.

```
[2016-06-30T18:03:49.471Z] [INFO] [#tid_65] [LoadBalancerService] user has 1 activations posted. Posted to invoke0[0][0]
[2016-06-30T18:05:01.685Z] [INFO] [#tid_72] [LoadBalancerService] user has 2 activations posted. Posted to invoke0[0][1]
[2016-06-30T18:06:09.062Z] [INFO] [#tid_77] [LoadBalancerService] user has 3 activations posted. Posted to invoke0[0][2]
[2016-06-30T18:07:17.123Z] [INFO] [#tid_86] [LoadBalancerService] user has 4 activations posted. Posted to invoke0[0][3]
```

[2016-06-30T18:07:41.898Z] [INFO] [#tid_72] [Dispatcher] matching message to 1 handlers: invoker
[2016-06-30T18:07:41.899Z] [INFO] [#tid_77] [Dispatcher] matching message to 1 handlers: invoker

Ready for merge.
I'm running locally with ansible 2.1.0.0 and have encountered no problems.

Please review.
Please review.
I'm working on providing instructions on how to re-deploy openwhisk after restarting the Vagrant VM.

Closing as not reproducible with the new Vagrant flow.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/vagrant
This is merged f0a702ff44a4b5c5ae3fc13242318025b1c9bb26

actions.md add simple example with promises, 
in references.md mark async and done as deprecated and provide more in depth details about promises (i.e. how to use bluebird, q, etc..) @bjustin-ibm might have better ideas on how to structure this.
Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/d2d241bd2ce9521c793fe6594bb4248f0076169c.
@lehoanganh let me verify it.
@lehoanganh let me verify it.

The PR above improved the experience for the second build. Is there any way to speed up the first build? It takes me roughly `Total time: 3 mins 53.77 secs` to build the go CLI on a 2.8 GHz Intel Core i7 with 16GB RAM (docker machine has 4GB RAM). And I'm on a wired network.
@lehoanganh let me verify it.

I also tried this command

```
./bin/go-cli/wsk action create a b c -i
error: Unable to create action: error: Request failure: error: exec undefined (code 201)
```

This should report a usage error, not make an API request.

As a constructive criticism, build and deploy is very confusing. Ant, gradle, ansible, some python scripts, a lot of environment variable and properties. Getting rid of ant is definetely positive.

And it's hard to know which variables are "build" time variables or "deployment" time variables. I believe (from experience) most are deployment variables, but I don't know for sure if any of them are baked into the resulting docker images.

After a battle I managed to build and deploy locally on my mac, using docker for mac beta, only for the sake of understanding the whole build and deploy process.

Travis failed.

```
system.basic.ActionTests > Actions CLI should suceed on an action staying within its time limits FAILED

    org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: "{"error":"action exceeded its time limits of 10000 milliseconds"}" did not include substring "[OK] message terminated successfully"
```

Not affected by the flip - so test might have a heisenbug (and a typo).

Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/4874e5703ff66180e2b5cdf148a675b8514bc7a3.

Fixed typo in test name while at it.

So I create a package and make it public. Then I update the package and don't provide --shared, it becomes private?

```
rr [pr-810] openwhisk> bin/go-cli/wsk package get p -i
ok: got package p
{
    "namespace": "rabbah@us.ibm.com",
    "name": "p",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "publish": false,
    "parameters": [],
    "binding": {}
}
rr [pr-810] openwhisk> bin/go-cli/wsk package update p -i --shared
ok: updated package p
rr [pr-810] openwhisk> bin/go-cli/wsk package get p -i
ok: got package p
{
    "namespace": "rabbah@us.ibm.com",
    "name": "p",
    "version": "0.0.2",
    "publish": true,
    "parameters": [],
    "binding": {}
}
rr [pr-810] openwhisk> bin/go-cli/wsk package update p -i 
ok: updated package p
rr [pr-810] openwhisk> bin/go-cli/wsk package get p -i
ok: got package p
{
    "namespace": "rabbah@us.ibm.com",
    "name": "p",
    "version": "0.0.3",
    "publish": false,
    "parameters": [],
    "binding": {}
}
```

This is "surprising". This requires that the user always provides `--shared` to preserve status. This is not consistent with other parameters being updated (i.e., user doesn't provider --parameters on every update to preserve parameters).
Exactly. I can close this PR, and leave it the way it is to accept arguments.

I'm inclined to agree. Let others weigh in.
The alternative is perhaps to do `--share` and `--no-share` options.

Thanks for the feedback @tuler. We're in a transition state and removing `ant` throughout.

`gradle` for building.
`ansible` for deploying.

There are a few more scripts related to deployment that haven't made it into playbooks.
We are working on updated documentation as well.

All of the parameters are intended for deployment parameters (i.e.,`whisk.properties`) or used for tests.
@markusthoemmes confirm?
Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/99d3e9ab82756631285072ad551398fa6b034e21. One small tweak reviewed with @csantanapr.
rebase and merged 659fd347c4e15a0a68862e2bc6ca3c5e33659c2a
good to merge.

Correct, there shouldn't really be any `build`-time variables. `gradle` can be told to use a specific **registry** or **dockertag** and thelike, nothing which should mangle with our really be "baked into" our images.

`ansible` is solely used to take the images generated by `gradle` and deploy them using a certain configuration. Tests are a bit mangled in currently, as in they rely on `whisk.properties` being written for them to run, so they only work in a combination of `ansible` (writing the property file) and gradle (running the tests)

Looks good to me, will merge when we have the example in docs+tests. Feel free to use additional commits as the blame shouldn't fall on the original author when the tests fail :)  As a point of curiosity, since the change is in the common container, does this mean we can use, e.g. bluebird packaged with webpack, and work with promises in the Node 0.9 container?
Will make it to `master` through #781. Thanks again!
@rabbah: no, `gradle` should **not** rely on `whisk.properties` being written. Tests are the only exemption.
@rabbah please give it a try and merge
I'm not sure about the usage of `openwhisk_fresh.yml`?
@rabbah - What is the expected behavior when an action with no code is invoked?  Just wondering if that should also be part of this test.

Right now, the Go CLI is building binaries for all of the Go supported platforms and architectures.  If some of these binaries are not needed we can remove them from the build.
- windows: 386, amd64
- mac: 386 amd64 arm arm64
- linux: 386 amd64 arm arm64 ppc64 ppc64le mips64 mips64le

@nauerz-ibm - Do you have a suggestion for the recommended Go `wsk` CLI binaries?  From the Bluemix CLI download page: Linux amd64 only, Windows amd64 only, Mac: ?? (I only have Windows)
Here's the Bluemix CLI download page: https://clis.ng.bluemix.net/ui/home.html
@rabbah @mdeuser please close if the problem on docker is fix now.
I was able to confirm that https://$APIHOST/cli/go/download/ now contains the go CLIs 👍

docs updated to use 1.9.1
readme in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/macos

The SSH command responded with a non-zero exit status. Vagrant
assumes that this means the command failed. The output for this command
should be in the log above. Please read the output to determine what
went wrong.

This is my command

OW_DB=couchdb OW_DB_USERNAME=admin OW_DB_PASSWORD=86889125 OW_DB_PROTOCOL=http OW_DB_HOST=127.0.0.1 OW_DB_PORT=5984   ./hello

running on windows7
Client: Git bash

Should the whisk/trigger.go have the following update similar to the action, package and rule modules?
In the `Trigger` struct used to encode the JSON sent to the server:

```
Publish bool `json:"publish,omitempty"`
```

change to

```
Publish bool `json:"publish"`  // remove the omitempty
```
Me neither, why not just run `wipe.yml` and `postdeploy.yml` seperately? Having too many different versions as compositions of `openwhisk.yml` will bring us to the same hell `ant` did.
@csantanapr - what was the $APIHOST value you used?
Are these tested yet?
No.  Test case issue -> #782
